Package com.phasmidsoftware.dsaipg.adt.pq

Class PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap<K>

java.lang.Object
com.phasmidsoftware.dsaipg.adt.pq.PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap<K>
Type Parameters:
K -
All Implemented Interfaces:
PriorityQueue<K>, Iterable<K>
public class PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap<K> extends Object implements PriorityQueue<K>, Iterable<K>
Priority Queue Data Structure which uses a binary heap.

It is unlimited in capacity, although there is no code to grow it after it has been constructed. It can serve as a minPQ or a maxPQ (define "max" as either false or true, respectively).

It can support the root at index 1 or the root at index 0 variants.

It operates on arbitrary Object types which implies that it requires a Comparator to be passed in.

For all details on usage, please see PriorityQueueTest.java CONSIDER why do we need to implement Iterable?

  • Constructor Details

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(boolean max, Object[] binHeap, int first, int m, Comparator<K> comparator, boolean floyd)
      Primary constructor that takes the max value, an actual array of elements, and a comparator.
      Parameters:
      max - whether or not this is a Maximum Priority Queue as opposed to a Minimum PQ.
      binHeap - a pre-formed array with length sufficient to accommodate all required elements plus any unused array slots.
      first - the index of the root element.
      m - the number of elements in binHeap
      comparator - a comparator for the type K
      floyd - true if we use Floyd's trick (aka snake).

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(int n, int first, boolean max, Comparator<K> comparator, boolean floyd)
      Secondary constructor which takes only the priority queue's maximum capacity and a comparator
      Parameters:
      n - the desired maximum capacity.
      first - the index to use for the first (root) element.
      max - whether or not this is a Maximum Priority Queue as opposed to a Minimum PQ.
      comparator - a comparator for the type K
      floyd - true if we use Floyd's trick (aka snake).

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(int n, boolean max, Comparator<K> comparator, boolean floyd)
      Constructs a priority queue with specified capacity, type (max or min), a comparator, and an option to use Floyd's heap construction algorithm.
      Parameters:
      n - the desired maximum capacity of the priority queue.
      max - if true, this is a Maximum Priority Queue; if false, it is a Minimum Priority Queue.
      comparator - a comparator for the type K to define the priority order.
      floyd - if true, Floyd's heap construction algorithm will be used.

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(int n, boolean max, Comparator<K> comparator)
      Secondary constructor which takes only the priority queue's maximum capacity and a comparator. Floyd is false and first is always 1.
      Parameters:
      n - the desired maximum capacity.
      max - whether or not this is a Maximum Priority Queue as opposed to a Minimum PQ.
      comparator - a comparator for the type K

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(int n, Comparator<K> comparator)
      Secondary constructor which takes only the priority queue's maximum capacity and a comparator. Other parameter values: max = true; first = 0; floyd = true.
      Parameters:
      n - the desired maximum capacity.
      comparator - a comparator for the type K

    • PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap

      public PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap(Collection<K> ks, Comparator<K> comparator)
      Secondary constructor which takes a Collection to be added immediately and a comparator. Other parameter values: n = ks.size; max = true; first = 0; floyd = true. This constructor uses the O(n) heap construction method (sometimes also known as "Floyd's Trick."). This constructor is suitable for use by HeapSort.
      Parameters:
      ks - a Collection of K elements.
      comparator - a comparator for the type K

    • give

      public void give(K key)
      Adds a key to the priority queue. If the priority queue is at its capacity, the last element is removed to make space for the new key. CONSIDER we can prevent the new element displacing a higher-priority element but at the cost of an extra comparison. Is that worth it?
      Specified by:
      give in interface PriorityQueue<K>
      Parameters:
      key - the element to be inserted into the priority queue

    • take

      public K take() throws PQException
      Remove the root element from this Priority Queue and adjust the binary heap accordingly. If max is true, then the result will be the maximum element, else the minimum element. NOTE that this method is sometimes called DelMax (or DelMin).
      Specified by:
      take in interface PriorityQueue<K>
      Returns:
      If max is true, then the maximum element, otherwise the minimum element.
      Throws:
      PQException - if this priority queue is empty

    • heapConstructor

      public void heapConstructor()
      Initializes or reconstructs the binary heap to satisfy the heap property for all elements. This method assumes the binary heap is stored in an array-like structure. Starting from the last non-leaf node, it applies the sink operation iteratively to ensure the heap invariant is maintained across all levels. The heap property ensures that each parent node is greater than or less than its children depending on whether the heap is configured as a max-heap or min-heap. The Floyd's heap construction approach might be invoked if it matches the configuration.
      Specified by:
      heapConstructor in interface PriorityQueue<K>

    • iterator

      @NotNull public Iterator<K> iterator()
      Non-mutating iterator over all values of this PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap. NOTE: after the first element, there is no definite ordering of the remaining elements. NOTE: this method is really not truly a method of the PriorityQueue_BinaryHeap API. It is here only for convenience.
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<K>
      Returns:
      an iterator based on a copy of the underlying array.

    • peek

      public K peek(int k)
      Retrieves the element at the specified position in the binary heap without removing it. WARNING: this is primarily for testing -- not recommended for general use.
      Specified by:
      peek in interface PriorityQueue<K>
      Parameters:
      k - the index of the element to peek at in the binary heap. The index must be within the valid range of elements.
      Returns:
      the element of type K at the specified index in the binary heap.

    • getMax

      public boolean getMax()
      Gets the max property of this priority queue. WARNING: this is primarily for testing -- not recommended for general use.
      Specified by:
      getMax in interface PriorityQueue<K>
      Returns:
      true if this priority queue is configured as a max-heap, false if it is configured as a min-heap.
